metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax v. Insurance Company

facts.text: The respondent is a company carrying on life, fire, marine and general insurance business.
The dispute relates to assessment of excess profits tax on income from business other than life insurance for chargeable accounting periods ending December 31, 1940, and December 31, 1941.
Insurance policies concerned are issued for short periods or ad hoc; fire policies normally for one year; whole premium received upfront.
Company prepares annual statements: premiums fully included as assets, 40% as reserve for unexpired risks shown as liability.
Example: In 1939, Rs. 1,00,000 premiums received, Rs. 40,000 shown as reserve for unexpired risks; balance as net profits.
In 1940, 1939 reserve of Rs. 40,000 treated as assets; fresh policies issued with new reserve.
This method is usual for insurance companies and approved accountancy practice.
High Court of Calcutta on reference under s.66(1) Income-tax Act read with s.21 Excess Profits Tax Act answered against appellant, granted certificate under s.66A.
Statements to Controller of Insurance disclosed 40% reserves as liability, allowed in income-tax assessment.

legal_issues.text: Whether amounts shown by insurance company as reserves for unexpired risks on pending policies are liable to be deducted under r.2 of Sch.II to the Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 from capital employed.

petitioner_arguments.text: All premiums received treated as capital under r.1 Sch.II; reserves for unexpired risks (Rs.40,000 in example) are outstanding liability/accruing liability to be deducted under r.2 Sch.II.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act; Sun Insurance Office v. Clark

petitioner_arguments.text: Contract of insurance complete on issuance; risk attaches, liability accruing as it can ripen anytime during policy.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sun Insurance Office v. Clark (House of Lords)

respondent_arguments.text: Provision for unexpired risks is contingent liability, not within r.2 Sch.II.
r.2 originally for borrowed money/debts; accruing liabilities added by amendment but as part of debts; unexpired risks not debt.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act XLII 1940 s.10; Webb v. Stenton; Israelson v. Dawson

court_reasoning.text: Reserves allowable deduction for income-tax under s.10 Income-tax Act Sch. r.6 as per accounts under Insurance Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: One condition of r.2 Sch.II satisfied.

court_reasoning.text: Issue is whether reserve is 'sum in respect of accruing liabilities'; insurance contract contingent but for tax, per Sun Insurance, treated as present liability for profits computation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinguishes income-tax from excess profits tax.

court_reasoning.text: Excess Profits Tax scheme taxes profits over standard profits based on capital employed; r.1 includes all assets utilised in business; r.2 deducts borrowed money, debts, accruing liabilities of same character.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Accruing liabilities must be profit-earning assets utilised in business.

court_reasoning.text: Reserve for unexpired risks not real trading asset contributing to profits; 'something in the air', no effect on business working.
Sun Insurance principle (unearned premium/liability as unpaid price) inapplicable; Northern Aluminium case applies: contingent liability not accruing for excess profits tax capital computation.

holdings.text: Reserve for unexpired risks in pending policies is not a sum in respect of accruing liability within r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act and cannot be deducted from capital employed.

precedents_cited.relevance: For income-tax, reserves for unexpired risks deductible as present liability/unearned premium.

precedents_cited.case_name: General Accident Fire and Life Assurance Corporation v. McGowan
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished by House of Lords in Sun Insurance.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gresham Life Assurance Society v. Styles
precedents_cited.relevance: Receipts not profits until cost of earning deducted.

precedents_cited.case_name: Scottish Union and National Insurance Company v. Smiles
precedents_cited.relevance: No allowance for unexpired risks; doubted by Lord Haldane.
Debt is debitum in praesenti, solvendum in futuro.

precedents_cited.case_name: Israelson v. Dawson (Port of Manchester Insurance Co., Ltd., Garnishees)
precedents_cited.relevance: Insurance payout not debt until compensation determined.

precedents_cited.case_name: Southern Railway of Peru Ltd. v. Owen
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguishes contingent liability from payment on contingency; Sun Insurance liability in praesenti.

precedents_cited.case_name: Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Inland Revenue Commissioners
precedents_cited.relevance: Conditional liability under contract not accruing liability for excess profits tax.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inland Revenue Commissioners v. Northern Aluminium Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Affirmed no accruing liability for excess profits tax capital.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940 (XV of 1940)
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge on excess profits over standard profits based on capital employed; rules for capital computation exclude accruing liabilities if qualifying.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Insurance profits per annual accounts furnished under Insurance Act; reserves allowed as deduction.

statutes_cited.name: Insurance Act, 1938
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires annual accounts to Controller of Insurance.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Amendment Act, 1940 (XLII of 1940)
statutes_cited.relevance: Amended r.2 Sch.II to include accruing liabilities as part of debts.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. Reserves for unexpired risks are not accruing liabilities deductible under r.2 Sch.II Excess Profits Tax Act from capital employed.
outcome.relief_granted: None to appellant; upholds High Court decision denying deduction.

key_quotes.text: "The reserve liability could not factually be said to have contributed to the running of the business or the earning of profits. It was something in the air."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning why reserve not accruing liability.

key_quotes.text: "A purely contingent liability, which may or may not mature, is not one which falls within that language..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Lord Greene from Northern Aluminium on contingent liabilities.

key_quotes.text: "There is... a fundamental distinction between a contingent liability and a payment dependent on a contingency."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Southern Railway distinguishing insurance liability.
